image.title: Escape from R'lyeh
image.caption:
If you particularly like this drawing, you can get it on a t-shirt via CafePress.

Steam had not been suffered to go down entirely, despite the departure of all hands for the shore; and it was the work of only a few moments of feverish rushing up and down between wheel and engines to get the Alert under way. Slowly, amidst the distorted horrors of that indescribable scene, she began to churn the lethal waters; whilst on the masonry of that charnel shore that was not of earth the titan Thing from the stars slavered and gibbered like Polypheme cursing the fleeing ship of Odysseus. Then, bolder than the storied Cyclops, great Cthulhu slid greasily into the water and began to pursue with vast wave-raising strokes of cosmic potency.

H.P. Lovecraft, The Call of Cthulhu

An experiment with applying ink with a brush, which I had done only once before, and never to detailed work. Details were enhanced with pens. My drawing was based, naturally enough, on Lovecraft’s description of Cthulhu:

A pulpy, tentacled head surmounted a grotesque and scaly body with rudimentary wings … It represented a monster of vaguely anthropoid outline, but with an octopus-like head whose face was a mass of feelers, a scaly, rubbery-looking body, prodigious claws on hind and fore feet, and long, narrow wings behind. This thing, which seemed instinct with a fearsome and unnatural malignancy, was of a somewhat bloated corpulence …

Ibid.

Some of the reasons my Cthulhu looks a bit unlike a lot of depictions have to do with paying attention to that: Note rudimentary wings, for instance, and bloated corpulence.

image.caption: I think the title says it all. The scan quality is not the best; some of the finer details (such as the teeth) don’t show up well or at all, but I'm reasonably happy with the image in general.

image.title: Dread Sentry
image.caption: The Dread Sentry is vaguely inspired by a death knight in a planned RPG campaign of my own design (that may or may not ever get off the ground). It was drawn in two classes; sketched in one and fleshed out in another. Unfortunately, it does not at all portray the power of the death knight whom I had in mind—nevertheless, as a picture, I am reasonably content with it.

image.title: Black Magic
image.caption:
A dark wizard hard at work; I'm not sure what he’s brewing, but I’m reasonably certain it's both more potent and more malicious than your average witch’s brew.

This picture was drawn as a (very belated) Christmas gift for my good friend Sheepy, who is in possession of the original (and who scanned it for me after my scan mysteriously disappeared), for which reason I put more effort into the details than I normally do (though unfortunately, many of those details are somewhat too small to show up well at this resolution). She requested something representative of what I like to draw: Goblins and eyeballs and stuff—voilà!

Other than a horrible mistake in inking, mostly covered up (but still present and as you see it), I'm rather pleased with it. Ah, and incidentally, the imp and cherub are the classical cartoon representations of the wizard’s conscience.
image.details: Ink pens over mechanical pencil sketch.

image.title: The Fury of Stormwing
image.caption: Tormented by unsatiable hunger and burning with the fire that was in him, raving and ravenous, Stormwing, greatest of all the flying dragons in their first Age, went on a rampage, razing cities and burning or devouring every living thing in his path. Ultimately, it took the concerted efforts of the Dragonlord and the one who would much later become greatest of the Dragonlords to slay the beast.
image.details: Ink pens (mechanical pencil sketch, since erased).

image.title: Doom
image.caption: A doodle I did on a bus and refined whilst waiting for a ferry; quick work and fairly small, but I’m quite pleased with it. To me there appears to be a certain power in him—but I find this power easier to represent in this image than in words, so I shall be less long-winded here than is customary for me.

image.title: Barbarian Warrior
image.caption:
A barbarian warrior, delivering his challenge with posture.

This was done during a short break in drawing class (yes, I took a basic drawing class). We had just been introduced to the basics of gesture drawing, and I felt like applying what I percieved to be the central concept to something more free and fun, drawn from my head, not life. Nothing fancy; it's just an attempt to convey a sense of movement.

image.title: The Dragon Summoner
image.caption:
What few wizards seem to realise is that summoning a servant is not the most important part. Mastering the servant is.

This is really the second version of a much (much) older picture. Unfortunately, you cannot compare and contrast the two because the older version is also much too poor for me to display here without feeling embarrassed.

image.caption: One of many renditions of my favourite random Evil Goblin™.

image.title: Freedom!
image.caption:
A Golem, Demon or God of the Earth—I don't know which—breaks free after eons of being trapped within the cold darkness of the bedrock. With a force that can tear mountains asunder and the pain of stone torn apart, it surfaces at last to walk the world anew—but to what purpose, I cannot say.

While it’s obviously a rough drawing, drawn with a much softer pencil than I’m prone to use, I'm quite pleased with this as an anatomical study—please tell me what’s wrong with it if you find anything, but bear in mind that it was done entirely without reference, although Lori helped me by pointing out a mistake (now fixed) I made with the pectoral muscles. I'm also fairly pleased with the dynamics—for once I'm fairly sure that he looks like he’s moving…

image.title: The First Harbinger
image.caption:
It stood by the dead tree, turning its head this way and that, then entered the clearing. … Pale light glinted now and then from its eyes, but although their cover was imperfect it seemed not to notice them. There was a frightening intelligence in its eyes…sharp and bright and filled with a palpable malevolence.

It appeared to be unarmed, though it was difficult to tell; it could easily be hiding an entire arsenal of knives and guns among the black rags and tatters of its garments. Only the hood was in marginally good shape, frayed around the edges but whole enough to conceal most of the Harbinger’s features. He could see a flash of pale skin, though; its chin, open to the light, was a deathly white, as were its thin lips. Finally giving up it hissed softly, flashing a set of white fangs, and stalked off in the brush.

Omen, the First Harbinger, is one of the most mysterious and resourceful servants of the sorcerer Nekros, a product of the Necromancer’s twisted magic. An undead creature possessed of both unnatural strength and a wicked cunning he hunts down relentlessly both those who oppose his master and those who fail him.
image.details: Ink pens over mechanical pencil sketch.

image.title: The Dragonlord
image.caption: The Dragonlord, leaning against a wall after a battle, tired not in the body but in the spirit after centuries of fighting and killing. If you think I drew him with the face turned away just so I wouldn't have to draw it, you’re right (I tried, I failed), but I rather like the result, anyway.
